metadata.notes: Primary PQC key encapsulation standard. Currently deployed in hybrid mode alongside classical algorithms (e.g., X25519 + ML-KEM). Designed to eventually replace ECDH/RSA for key agreement once confidence in lattice-based security matures.

Primary PQC digital signature standard. Not yet deployed in hybrid TLS or certificate chains at scale. Intended to eventually replace RSA/ECDSA for authentication, but hybrid signature schemes are still being standardized by IETF.

Conservative hash-based signature scheme. Slower and larger signatures than ML-DSA, but based on minimal security assumptions (hash function security only). Intended as a fallback if lattice-based schemes are broken. Not yet deployed in hybrid protocols.

NIST Round 4 evaluation. ~30% more compact signatures than ML-DSA, but harder to implement securely due to floating-point arithmetic requirements. Future alternative for bandwidth-constrained applications. Not yet available for hybrid deployment.

metadata.description: Hybrid post-quantum key exchange for TLS 1.3 combining ML-KEM with X25519
metadata.notes: Hybrid key exchange pairs ML-KEM with X25519 so that the connection remains secure even if one algorithm is broken. Required for PQC-protected HTTPS, API calls, and any TLS-based communication. Most critical protocol for broad PQC adoption. Pure PQC-only TLS is not yet standardized.

ietf_drafts.name: draft-ietf-tls-ecdhe-mlkem
ietf_drafts.title: Post-quantum hybrid ECDHE-MLKEM Key Agreement for TLSv1.3

ietf_drafts.name: draft-ietf-tls-mlkem
ietf_drafts.title: ML-KEM Post-Quantum Key Agreement for TLS 1.3

metadata.description: Hybrid post-quantum key exchange for SSH protocol
metadata.notes: Defines hybrid key exchange combining ML-KEM with X25519 for secure shell connections. OpenSSH 10.0 already uses mlkem768x25519-sha256 as its default hybrid KEX. Authentication (host keys, user keys) remains classical RSA/Ed25519 -- hybrid signatures for SSH are not yet specified.

metadata.description: X.509 certificate formats for ML-KEM, ML-DSA, and SLH-DSA keys
metadata.notes: Defines how PQC keys are encoded in X.509 certificates for TLS authentication, code signing, and PKI. Hybrid certificate formats (carrying both classical and PQC keys) are under active IETF discussion. Full deployment blocked until CAs issue hybrid or PQC-only certificates.

ietf_drafts.name: draft-ietf-lamps-pq-composite-sigs
ietf_drafts.title: Composite ML-DSA for use in X.509 Public Key Infrastructure

metadata.description: Post-quantum key exchange for QUIC transport protocol
metadata.notes: QUIC uses TLS 1.3 for its handshake, so PQC QUIC inherits hybrid key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM) from the TLS PQC hybrid design. Already deployed in hybrid mode in Chrome 131+ via BoringSSL.

metadata.description: Post-quantum key exchange for Datagram TLS
metadata.notes: DTLS is used for real-time and IoT communications. PQC support follows from TLS PQC hybrid design, combining ML-KEM with classical key exchange. wolfSSL already supports hybrid DTLS.

metadata.description: Post-quantum key exchange and authentication for IPSec/IKEv2
metadata.notes: Critical for VPN and network-layer encryption. Hybrid PQC key exchange and authentication specifications for IKEv2 are still in early IETF drafting stages. No production hybrid IPSec deployments yet.

metadata.description: Widely used open-source crypto library (LTS release)
metadata.notes: OpenSSL 3.5 (April 2025, LTS) includes ML-KEM, ML-DSA, and SLH-DSA algorithms. Hybrid key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM) available in TLS 1.3. ML-DSA and SLH-DSA available as standalone APIs but not yet integrated into TLS handshake for hybrid authentication. Foundation for most server-side hybrid PQC.

fips.notes: OpenSSL 3.0.x FIPS provider has FIPS 140-3 validation (classical algorithms). OpenSSL 3.5.4 submitted for new FIPS 140-3 validation with PQC algorithms (ML-KEM, ML-DSA) in boundary -- CMVP review pending. Would be the first FIPS module with PQC.

metadata.description: Mozilla's Network Security Services library, used in Firefox and RHEL
metadata.notes: NSS 3.112 includes ML-KEM support for hybrid TLS 1.3 key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM). ML-DSA under active development, expected in future releases. Hybrid authentication (ML-DSA certificates) not yet available. RHEL 10.0 ships NSS 3.112.

fips.notes: Listed as 'Implementation Under Test' for RHEL 10.0. No active FIPS 140-3 certificate. Current testing does not include PQC algorithms.

metadata.description: GNU Transport Layer Security library, widely used in GNOME and RHEL
metadata.notes: GnuTLS in RHEL 10 supports ML-KEM hybrid TLS 1.3 key exchange: X25519MLKEM768, SecP256r1MLKEM768, and SecP384r1MLKEM1024. Used by many GNOME applications and system services. ML-DSA signature support not yet available in GnuTLS.

fips.notes: GnuTLS does not currently have FIPS 140-3 validation.

metadata.description: Google's OpenSSL fork powering Chrome and Android
metadata.notes: ML-KEM fully standardized via openssl/mlkem.h (prestandard Kyber API removed). ML-DSA-65 public API available via openssl/mldsa.h with key generation and signing. Hybrid X25519MLKEM768 deployed in Chrome 131+ by default for all TLS 1.3 connections. Internal Google project, not intended for general external use.

fips.notes: BoringCrypto module FIPS 140-3 validated (cert #5104, Apr 2024). Current certificate covers classical algorithms only; PQC not yet in FIPS boundary. Multiple pending validations in 2025.

metadata.description: Go's built-in crypto implementation (independent, no OpenSSL dependency)
metadata.notes: Go 1.23 introduced X25519Kyber768Draft00 hybrid key exchange in crypto/tls. Go 1.24 adds dedicated crypto/mlkem package implementing FIPS 203. Production-ready hybrid PQC for TLS 1.3 and QUIC. ML-DSA support expected in Go 1.27; hybrid authentication not yet available.

fips.notes: Go 1.24 includes FIPS 140-3 compliance mode (crypto/internal/fips140). No CMVP certificate yet. Designed to facilitate compliance; formal validation pending.

metadata.description: Java/Kotlin cryptography library with comprehensive PQC algorithm support
metadata.notes: API support for ML-KEM and ML-DSA as standalone algorithms. No direct hybrid TLS protocol integration; used as a JCA provider for Java applications that need raw PQC operations. Hybrid TLS requires JDK-level support.

fips.notes: Bouncy Castle FIPS Java API (bc-fips) exists but does not yet include PQC algorithms. Current FIPS module covers classical algorithms only.

metadata.description: Modern TLS library written in Rust
metadata.notes: Experimental hybrid PQC TLS support via rustls-post-quantum crate with prefer-post-quantum feature flag. X25519 + ML-KEM hybrid key exchange available but not yet stable. No hybrid signature support.

fips.notes: No FIPS 140-3 validation path. rustls uses aws-lc-rs or ring as crypto backends; aws-lc-rs has a separate FIPS path via AWS-LC.

metadata.description: Lightweight embedded-focused crypto library with CNSA 2.0 compliance
metadata.notes: Full ML-KEM and ML-DSA implementation with hybrid TLS 1.3 and DTLS support. Among the first crypto providers to support CNSA 2.0 hybrid requirements. Includes hash-based signatures (LMS, XMSS) for firmware signing. Supports both hybrid and pure PQC modes.

fips.notes: wolfCrypt FIPS 140-3 validated (cert #4718, Jul 2024, active through 2029). Also holds cert #5041. Validated on 80+ operating environments. Current certificates cover classical algorithms; PQC not yet in FIPS boundary.

metadata.description: Apple's native cryptography framework for iOS, macOS, and related platforms
metadata.notes: CryptoKit added ML-KEM and quantum-secure HPKE APIs at WWDC 2025. iOS 26/macOS Tahoe 26 enable hybrid TLS 1.3 (X25519MLKEM768) by default for URLSession and Network.framework. Proprietary, closed-source implementation tightly integrated with Apple platforms.

fips.notes: Apple corecrypto has had FIPS 140-2 validations historically. No public FIPS 140-3 validation with PQC algorithms.

metadata.description: Microsoft's core cryptographic library powering CNG (Cryptography: Next Generation) and SChannel on Windows
metadata.notes: ML-KEM and ML-DSA GA in Windows 11 24H2/25H2 and Windows Server 2025 (November 2025). Hybrid TLS 1.3 via SChannel (ML-KEM-768 + ECDH). CNG APIs expose ML-KEM and ML-DSA directly. Enterprise PKI via Active Directory Certificate Services planned for early 2026.

fips.notes: SymCrypt.dll FIPS 140-3 validated for classical algorithms. PQC algorithms (ML-KEM, ML-DSA) are in SymCrypt but not yet within the FIPS validation boundary.

metadata.notes: Ships OpenSSL 3.5 and NSS 3.112 with ML-KEM support. First enterprise Linux distribution with production hybrid PQC capabilities. Hybrid TLS 1.3 key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM) available out of the box. Hybrid authentication (ML-DSA certificates) not yet available at the OS level.

RHEL 9.7 introduced the PQ crypto-policy subpolicy enabling hybrid ML-KEM key exchange and ML-DSA signatures system-wide (update-crypto-policies --set DEFAULT:PQ). PQC is available across OpenSSL, GnuTLS, and NSS but requires explicit opt-in via the subpolicy. RHEL 9 versions prior to 9.7 do not have PQC support.
Ships OpenSSL 3.5 with hybrid PQC support. Fedora serves as the upstream proving ground for RHEL. Hybrid key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM) available ahead of enterprise adoption.

Ships OpenSSL 3.0.x which does not include PQC algorithm support. As an LTS release, it will not receive OpenSSL 3.5 backports. PQC requires upgrading to a newer Ubuntu release or manual OpenSSL compilation.

metadata.description: Microsoft Windows 11 with CNG cryptographic provider
metadata.notes: Windows CNG (Cryptography Next Generation) includes native ML-KEM and ML-DSA algorithm support starting with Windows 11 24H2 and Windows Server 2025. .NET 10 leverages CNG on Windows for PQC operations. Hybrid TLS integration at the OS/Schannel level is partial.

Ships LibreSSL which does not include PQC algorithm support. Applications needing PQC on macOS must bundle their own crypto library (e.g., Homebrew OpenSSL 3.5). macOS Tahoe 26 (2025) adds CryptoKit ML-KEM and hybrid TLS by default.

Hybrid quantum-secure TLS (X25519MLKEM768) enabled by default for URLSession and Network.framework. CryptoKit provides ML-KEM and quantum-secure HPKE APIs for custom protocols. First major mobile OS with PQC enabled by default.

Ships BoringSSL as system crypto library via Conscrypt JCA provider. Chrome on Android negotiates hybrid PQC TLS (X25519MLKEM768) by default since Chrome 124. System-wide hybrid TLS support depends on the BoringSSL version shipped with each Android release. Conscrypt does not yet expose ML-KEM APIs directly to app developers.

metadata.description: JavaScript runtime built on V8 and OpenSSL
metadata.notes: Node.js 24+ exposes ML-KEM and ML-DSA via the node:crypto API when linked against OpenSSL 3.5. Hybrid PQC TLS depends on the system OpenSSL version. No native hybrid TLS negotiation independent of OpenSSL -- inherits whatever hybrid support OpenSSL provides. Pure JS ML-KEM implementations (e.g., mlkem npm package) exist for application-layer use but are not production TLS paths.

The pyca/cryptography package (primary Python crypto library) currently delegates to OpenSSL but is actively moving away. As of Jan 2026, maintainers announced ML-KEM and ML-DSA APIs will only be available on BoringSSL/AWS-LC backends, not OpenSSL. Wheels are exploring switching from statically linked OpenSSL to a BoringSSL/AWS-LC fork. Pure Python PQC libraries exist (kyber-py, quantcrypt) but are research/educational only. Hybrid PQC TLS depends entirely on which backend the cryptography package links against.

metadata.description: Go programming language with built-in crypto
metadata.notes: Go 1.24 has production-ready hybrid ML-KEM key exchange for TLS 1.3 and QUIC (X25519 + ML-KEM). Independent implementation (no OpenSSL dependency). ML-DSA support expected in Go 1.27; hybrid authentication not yet available.

JDK 24 (GA March 2025) introduced native APIs for ML-KEM and ML-DSA in core Java security. JDK 25 LTS (September 2025) inherits these. Bouncy Castle provider adds additional PQC algorithm support. Hybrid TLS integration not yet available in JSSE -- applications cannot negotiate hybrid PQC key exchange natively.

ML-KEM crates available: libcrux-ml-kem (SIMD-accelerated), enc_rust (pure Rust). Rustls added experimental X25519 + ML-KEM hybrid key exchange. ML-DSA planned for enc_rust. All current PQC TLS usage is hybrid only.

.NET 10 (November 2025) introduced native MLKem and MLDsa classes for standalone PQC operations. Inherits hybrid TLS support from OpenSSL on Linux. Windows CNG integration includes native ML-KEM and ML-DSA algorithm access. Hybrid TLS negotiation depends on the underlying OS crypto provider.
No native PQC libraries. Relies on ruby/openssl gem bindings to system OpenSSL. Hybrid PQC key exchange available when linked with OpenSSL 3.5+ -- inherits hybrid support transparently.
No native PQC libraries. Entirely dependent on system OpenSSL via openssl extension. Hybrid PQC key exchange available when system provides OpenSSL 3.5+ -- inherits hybrid support transparently.

metadata.description: Secure JavaScript/TypeScript runtime built on V8 and BoringSSL
metadata.notes: Delegates all cryptography to BoringSSL. Hybrid PQC TLS key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM) inherited from BoringSSL when available. No independent PQC implementation path -- fully delegated to the underlying crypto engine.

metadata.description: Fast JavaScript/TypeScript runtime built on JavaScriptCore and BoringSSL
metadata.notes: Delegates all cryptography to BoringSSL. Hybrid PQC TLS key exchange (X25519 + ML-KEM) inherited from BoringSSL when available. No independent PQC implementation path -- fully delegated to the underlying crypto engine.

OpenSSH 10.0 (April 2025) uses mlkem768x25519-sha256 as default hybrid key exchange, combining ML-KEM with X25519 via OpenSSL 3.5. Key exchange is hybrid PQC; authentication (host keys, user keys) remains classical RSA/Ed25519. Hybrid or PQC-only signatures not yet implemented.

metadata.description: High-performance web server and reverse proxy
metadata.notes: Inherits hybrid PQC TLS 1.3 key exchange when compiled with OpenSSL 3.5+. Requires ssl_conf_command to enable hybrid cipher suites (X25519 + ML-KEM). No code changes needed in nginx itself -- hybrid support is transparent from OpenSSL.
Inherits hybrid PQC TLS 1.3 key exchange when compiled with OpenSSL 3.5+. SSLCipherSuite configuration may need updates to enable hybrid KEMs (X25519 + ML-KEM).
Inherits hybrid PQC TLS 1.3 key exchange when compiled with OpenSSL 3.5+. Used for load balancing and hybrid TLS termination in enterprise infrastructure.

metadata.description: Command-line tool and library for transferring data
metadata.notes: Inherits hybrid PQC TLS 1.3 key exchange when compiled with OpenSSL 3.5+. libcurl is embedded in countless applications. Automatic hybrid PQC for any app using libcurl with updated OpenSSL.
Inherits hybrid PQC TLS 1.3 key exchange when compiled with OpenSSL 3.5+. Database client-server connections can use hybrid PQC cipher suites for quantum-resistant data-in-transit protection.

Control plane uses Go (ML-KEM available in Go 1.24+). Runs on RHEL with OpenSSL providing the crypto foundation. HAProxy-based ingress router inherits PQC TLS when compiled with OpenSSL 3.5+. Identity (X.509 cluster PKI) and image signing (Sigstore/cosign) remain classical.

transport.note: Go 1.24+ ML-KEM in TLS handshake for API server and inter-component communication

identity.note: X.509 certificate signing still uses classical RSA/ECDSA

ingress.note: HAProxy + OpenSSL 3.5+ path exists for hybrid PQC TLS termination

secrets.note: etcd encryption at rest uses AES-256, not PQC-impacted

signing.note: Sigstore/cosign image signing uses classical algorithms

metadata.notes: Written in Go. Go 1.24+ provides native ML-KEM hybrid key exchange for TLS connections between API server, kubelet, etcd, and controllers. Cluster PKI (certificate signing) remains classical RSA/ECDSA. Ingress PQC readiness depends on the chosen ingress controller.

transport.note: Go 1.24+ ML-KEM hybrid key exchange for internal TLS

identity.note: Cluster PKI still uses classical RSA/ECDSA certificate signing

ingress.note: Depends on ingress controller and its crypto library

secrets.note: Secret encryption at rest uses AES, not PQC-impacted

metadata.notes: Written in Python, which has no native PQC TLS support. Runs on RHEL and delegates crypto to OpenSSL via the OS, but Python's ssl module does not yet expose PQC cipher suites. All transport and identity surfaces remain classical.

transport.note: Python ssl module does not expose PQC cipher suites

identity.note: Token and certificate handling uses classical algorithms

secrets.note: Vault encryption uses AES, not PQC-impacted

metadata.description: Service mesh with Envoy proxy data plane
metadata.notes: Istio control plane (istiod) is written in Go with ML-KEM available in Go 1.24+. Envoy proxy data plane uses BoringSSL which has ML-KEM and ML-DSA support, enabling hybrid PQC mTLS between services. Certificate signing via Citadel still uses classical algorithms.

transport.note: Envoy uses BoringSSL with ML-KEM for hybrid PQC mTLS between services

identity.note: Citadel certificate signing still uses classical RSA/ECDSA

ingress.note: Envoy gateway uses BoringSSL with PQC-capable TLS termination

metadata.notes: Java-based identity provider. Can use Bouncy Castle as a JCA provider which supports ML-KEM and ML-DSA, enabling hybrid PQC for TLS transport and potentially PQC token signing. Default JDK crypto provider does not yet include PQC algorithms (expected in Java 24+).

transport.note: Java TLS with Bouncy Castle provider enables hybrid PQC key exchange

identity.note: Bouncy Castle supports ML-DSA for token and certificate signing

secrets.note: Credential storage uses hashing/AES, not PQC-impacted

metadata.description: Secrets management and data protection platform
metadata.notes: Written in Go. Transport layer benefits from Go 1.24+ ML-KEM hybrid TLS. However, the PKI secrets engine (certificate signing), transit engine (encryption/signing), and seal/unseal operations all use classical algorithms. Vault's core secret management functions are not yet PQC-ready.

transport.note: Go 1.24+ ML-KEM hybrid key exchange for API and cluster TLS

identity.note: PKI secrets engine uses classical RSA/ECDSA for certificate signing

secrets.note: Seal/unseal and transit engine use classical encryption and signing

metadata.notes: Java-based. TLS for broker-to-broker and client-to-broker communication can use OpenSSL via Netty-tcnative for hybrid PQC key exchange. Alternatively, Bouncy Castle JCA provider adds PQC cipher suites. mTLS certificate authentication still uses classical signing algorithms.

transport.note: Java TLS via OpenSSL (Netty-tcnative) or Bouncy Castle for hybrid PQC

identity.note: mTLS certificates still use classical RSA/ECDSA signing

metadata.notes: Backend written in Python (no native PQC TLS) with some Go components. Runs on RHEL. Python's ssl module does not yet expose PQC cipher suites, and container image signing uses classical algorithms. PQC readiness blocked by Python ecosystem limitations.

transport.note: Python lacks native PQC TLS support

signing.note: Container image signing uses classical algorithms

metadata.notes: Managed Kubernetes on AWS. AWS infrastructure uses AWS-LC (s2n-tls), a BoringSSL fork with ML-KEM hybrid key exchange support. ALB/NLB load balancers support TLS 1.3 PQC via s2n-tls. EKS-issued cluster certificates still use classical signing.

transport.note: AWS-LC/s2n-tls supports ML-KEM hybrid key exchange

identity.note: EKS-issued certificates still use classical RSA/ECDSA

ingress.note: ALB supports TLS 1.3 PQC via s2n-tls

metadata.notes: Managed Kubernetes on Google Cloud. Google infrastructure uses BoringSSL with ML-KEM support across Google Front End (GFE) and Cloud Load Balancing. GKE cluster certificates still use classical signing algorithms.

transport.note: BoringSSL with ML-KEM in GFE and Cloud Load Balancing

identity.note: GKE cluster certificates still use classical signing

metadata.notes: Managed Kubernetes on Azure. Azure infrastructure uses SymCrypt/CNG with ML-KEM support for TLS. Azure PKI and AKS cluster certificates still use classical signing algorithms.

transport.note: SymCrypt with ML-KEM for hybrid PQC TLS

identity.note: Azure PKI still uses classical certificate signing
